0.text:
Hi everybody. In this video I thought I'd
start going through my collection of DVDs,

6.text:
just to show you what I have in case there's
anything that interests you, or if you have

10.text:
any similar tastes to mine. Some of the stuff
you might not like, some of it you may well

14.text: like, so we'll see how we go.

16.text:
I previously posted my music collection in
my blog before, which I might do a couple

21.text:
of videos on here as well. So I thought, well
why not do my DVDs too.

24.text:
So first up we have Doctor Who and Torchwood,
because Doctor Who is one of my favourite

31.text:
shows. I've only got the modern series from
2005 onwards. I've seen a few of the classic

37.text:
episodes on TV or on Netflix in the past,
but I've never really watched them properly.

41.text:
And I should, I know, I should get round to
that one day.

44.text:
But yeah, Doctor Who and Torchwood I do really
like. And the new Class spin-off that's been

52.text:
on recently - it's ok, it's not as good as
these but, you know, it's been reasonable

57.text:
viewing judging by the first episode anyway,
so we'll see how that goes.

62.text:
The first series of Doctor Who, I like this
box set in particular because It's in the

66.text:
shape of the Tardis. It's a big box that opens
up and it's packaged really nicely, and the

72.text:
artwork's really good. Obviously it would
have taken up far too much space if every

77.text:
series was like this. But for the first series
to be packaged in this way I thought was a

84.text:
It's a shame Christopher Eccleston didn't
do more than one series really, but he did

88.text: do a fantastic job on that first one. I think David Tennant's my favourite Doctor of all though.

95.text:
Then we have 24, which is another great show.
I got into it a little bit later than everyone

99.text:
else, I tend to be a bit behind on the trends.
But the BBC started repeating it, and I got

104.text:
into it and thought "yeah, this is pretty
awesome". Because you get to the end of each

108.text:
episode and think "oh yeah, I wanna watch
some more." So it is very addictive that show.

113.text:
And Knight Rider's a very cool show as well.
The new version they did in 2008, I've also

119.text:
got the DVD of that series, and that is quite
good too, you know. It had a lot of potential,

124.text:
so it was a shame that only ran for one series
really. But obviously it can't live up to

129.text:
the original. But it was still a good follow-up
to the original series.

134.text:
Then we've got The Professionals, which is
another great show. And, like all these shows

139.text:
I've been talking about already, has a brilliant
theme tune. This was released by a company

144.text:
called Network who remastered it, as they
did with The Sweeney as well, which you're

149.text:
now seeing here. They've done a really great
job at remastering these episodes with great

155.text:
sound and picture quality, so they really
look like they were made much more recently.

159.text: And they're all great shows these.

161.text:
And I've also got the two Sweeney films as
well. Not as good as the TV show perhaps,

166.text: but they're still good fun to watch. And I've got the Regan pilot that goes with The Sweeney as well.

171.text:
And then we've got Minder, which I've think
Network have got the rights to now, so I think

176.text:
they're gonna be remastering that, or I certainly
hope they're going to be, because it is a

180.text:
brilliant show. These older copies of the
DVDs are alright though, but certainly the

186.text:
quality could be better, and some of the menu
systems leave a little bit to be desired.

191.text:
Some of them don't have, like, the Play All
option, for instance. You have to select each

195.text: episode by hand. Which isn't a major deal, but it's still, you know, a little bit frustrating, I suppose.

202.text:
But, yeah, and even the Ray Daley years were
good. But obviously the originals with Terry

205.text:
McCann were the best. And I've also got the
series that Channel 5 did with Shane Richie

212.text:
taking over the role. And that was ok, It
wasn't too bad. Again, nowhere near as good

217.text:
as the original, but it was still good fun,
and the remake of the theme tune that The

221.text: Attic Lights did for that song was good too.

225.text:
And then, moving on to other series, we have
2Point4 Children, which I only have 3 series

229.text:
of, I think there's about 6 altogether. But
they stopped releasing after 3 series, I think

234.text:
partly because the sales weren't what they
hoped for, and also because there were rights

238.text:
issues with the later series, including a
Thunderbird car in particular in one episode.

242.text:
So it's a great shame, because it's a great
show.

245.text:
Al Murray's Happy Hour was a chat show he
did, it was a sort of a fun, sort of spoof

250.text:
chat show I suppose. But it was good fun,
and he was a big Queen fan so he often had

254.text: Queen songs on there, including Queen themselves in one finale for one series, so that was brilliant.

259.text:
'Allo 'Allo! Classic sitcom, absolute classic.
Great stories, great characters. The story

265.text:
got quite complicated sometimes, but it was
really, really funny and really well written,

269.text:
and really well acted. I haven't got the reunion
specials they did later on, but yeah, I've

275.text: got the main series, which is brilliant.

277.text:
Black Adder, another classic series of course.
Ok, the first series wasn't very good, but

282.text:
series 2, 3 and 4 and the millennium special
were all very good. And this box set's got

287.text:
everything on it, and loads of extras as well.
The millennium special they did I actually

292.text:
saw in the Dome, in the days when it was The
Millennium Dome, so that was quite good. That

295.text: was before it became the O2.

297.text:
An Idiot Abroad with Karl Pilkington, I've
got a few series of that. That's a good, fun

303.text:
show, you get to see some interesting places
as well, and some interesting people.

308.text:
Are You Being Served? Another classic sitcom.
Not perhaps top of my favourites list, but

312.text:
still good fun to watch. Again some great
characters and things like that.

317.text:
And then we've got a documentary here - The
Blue Planet. I haven't got any nature documentaries

323.text:
other than this. But I got this years ago,
because I saw it on the telly, and it is really

328.text:
well made, and some really stunning footage
on there.

332.text:
Then back to the comedy - The Big Bang Theory
of course. A friend of mine got me into it,

337.text:
and I've enjoyed watching it ever since. It's
one of the few American sitcoms I actually

342.text:
like. I'm not into Friends or things like
that. But The Big Bang Theory is one that

347.text: I really do like, it's really great.

349.text:
And then back to the drama again, we have
The Bill. These are the earliest series of

353.text:
The Bill, which I was too young to see when
they were released at the time. I got into

356.text:
The Bill obviously much later in the 90s.
So to be able to get to watch these classic

361.text:
earlier episodes is really good fun, it's
a really good show.

365.text:
And then Dangermouse - classic cartoon from
my youth. I mean, I don't really buy cartoons

371.text:
much, you know, from when I was a kid. But
this is a definite classic, with David Jason

376.text:
and Terry Scott. It's really, really good
fun. And the new version they did recently

380.text:
is also very good, to give it its credit,
what they've been showing with Alexander Armstrong

385.text:
on CBBC. So, yeah, give it its dues, they've
done a pretty good remake, which you can't

391.text:
say for a lot of TV shows. But certainly nothing
can surpass the original.

395.text:
And then this is MIT - Murder Investigation
Team - which was a little spin-off of The

399.text:
Bill, which was good fun. I saw it was released
and thought "well, why not get that, it's

405.text:
And then another of my favourite comedies
- Bottom - with the late, great and very sadly

409.text:
missed Rik Mayall. I have the live shows as
well but I got to those later, as I've got

413.text: a separate shelf for all that kind of stuff.

415.text:
The Brittas Empire with Chris Barrie, another
brilliant sitcom. Very, very funny. Very surreal

420.text:
in places and, yeah, it often gets overlooked,
forgotten about perhaps, but I've got all

425.text: the series of that, it's great fun.

428.text:
And then here's a show, a comedy action drama
show, whatever you want to call it, called

432.text:
Chuck, from America. Which was cancelled twice
I think, but the fans managed to get it back

437.text:
each time, and it ran for 5 series altogether
in the end. And I don't think a lot of people

442.text:
necessarily know about it in the UK, but it's
really, really good. I caught it on a Freeview

445.text:
channel once, and yeah, worth checking out.
It has a great soundtrack as well, the music

450.text:
The Fall And Rise Of Reginald Perrin - another
great sitcom. Again a bit surreal in places,

455.text: but very well acted by Leonard Rossiter.

458.text:
And Citizen Smith, starring Robert Lindsay,
and written by John Sullivan, the writer of

463.text:
Only Fools And Horses. This came before that.
And "Power To The People" - it's brilliant.

471.text:
And then this is a relatively little-known
sitcom called Clarence, starring Ronnie Barker,

476.text:
and Josephine Tewson who played Elizabeth
in Keeping Up Appearances. And, yeah, that's

480.text:
a good fun sitcom. Not one of the best ever,
but still fun.

483.text:
But this is definitely one of the best ever
- Dad's Army. I mean, what needs to be said?

488.text:
It is a sheer classic and it's just brilliant.
And actually, on the day I'm recording this,

495.text:
yesterday we had the news that Jimmy Perry,
one of the co-creators of the show, has passed

500.text:
away, very sadly. I think he was about 93.
And this is one hell of a legacy to leave

505.text:
behind. It's a really amazing creation that
him and David Croft put together. So, yeah,

511.text:
he'll be sadly missed, but he's certainly
left some great memories behind that people

514.text:
will continue to enjoy for many, many years.
It really is a true classic of the genre.

520.text:
And Derren Brown, I have a few of his DVDs,
and that's what I'm gonna finish this part

525.text:
with. I'm gonna split my collection into a
few bits, because there's quite a lot to get

529.text:
through. I've built up quite a lot over the
past 15-20 years. But yeah, I've got his Trick

535.text:
Of The Mind and his Mind Control DVDs and
things from his TV shows. And they're all

541.text:
very good, I'm a great admirer of what he
does.

543.text:
I've never seen him live, but I would certainly
love to see one of his live shows, and again

548.text:
I'll get to the DVDs I've got of those later.
I've kind of divided up my DVDs so all my

553.text:
TV shows are in one bit, all the live shows
are in another. I've got music DVDs as well

557.text:
which I'll get to. This is a DVD of his experiments,
including The Assassin, The Gameshow, The

565.text:
Guilt Trip and The Secret Of Luck. All of
which are all very interesting, he's very,

570.text: very good at what he does.

573.text:
So that's it for now, that's the first part
of my DVD collection done. I hope you found

577.text:
it interesting. If there's anything you like,
comment and let me know. But for now I will

584.text:
be back soon with the second part, so I will
see you then. Bye bye!
